docs.text: i read the new yorker magazine and i enjoy some of their really in-depth articles about some incident .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: they will take some incident like the investigation of a mysterious plane crash and tell you what happened in detail .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it becomes a real education in what agencies get involved and how theories are suggested , and what kind of pressure the investigators are under , and just about any other aspect you can think of .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: frequently i get the feeling that the article sounded exciting , but i am being told in more detail than i really wanted to know .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: often i get to the middle of a story and say , ok , it sounded good but i now have invested more time than i am willing to spend on this subject .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: film is a different medium .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it is a visual medium .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: that slows down the telling of stories much more than people realize .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i frequently am surprised to find out how short a film script is and how much of the pages are empty space .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the magazine article and the film script are two very different media .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the insider is a film adaptation of the vanity fair article " the man who knew too much " by marie brenner .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it is too much an adaptation of a magazine article slowed to the pace of a film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it really verges on being tedious at least at times .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: for years the seven big companies knew that they dealt in an addictive drug that caused a host of unhealthy side-effects .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but they pretended for the public that it was unproven and they did not really believe it .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the business was incredibly profitable and the proceeds translated into the political power to squelch and discredit any political movements against big tobacco .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the tide turned when a former vice-president of one of the companies was convinced by the cbs 60 minutes news team to tell the public how much the tobacco companies really knew about the health effects of smoking .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the resulting pressure to stop the story created a small civil war at cbs .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: who were the major people involved , what were their motives , how was the story almost killed , how did it get aired anyway ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: that is the story covered in surprising detail by the insider .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this all could have been enthralling , but it is not the sort of thing that a stylist like michael mann would be likely to do well .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: and in the end , he failed .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: to make a long story short , the film needed a director who knew how to make a long story short .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the film opens with the cbs 60 minutes team in iran with the assignment to interview a terrorist .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: we get a taste for their personal style and how they get the upper hand .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: they go from being one newsman blindfolded at the hands of the terrorists to the actual interview with mike wallace ( played by christopher plummer ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there the news team under producer lowell bergman ( al pacino ) are ordering around the terrorists and getting away with it .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this seems to have nothing to do with the main line of the story , but later when the tobacco industry is so much harder to manipulate than committed terrorists , we have a wry irony on who really has clout in the world .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: terrorists can grab the headlines , but the tobacco companies have the real position of power .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: incongruously intercut with the iran interview sequence we see jeffrey wigand ( russell crowe ) dejectedly returning from work to his home .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: we discover that he has been fired and his career brought to a complete halt unexpectedly .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he had been a very profitably rewarded vice-president in charge or research and development at brown and williams tobacco ; now he was unemployed and needed money to support his family .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: rather than support him his wife liane ( diane venora ) demands of him what are they supposed to do for income .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: meanwhile the 60 minutes team trying to do a story on fires started by cigarettes have obtained some data they do not understand .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: they offer wigand $12 , 000 just to interpret the data .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: wigand's severance agreement swears him to secrecy about anything he knows about tobacco dealings , but he is reluctantly he stretches the severance terms .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he is willing to read some documents from another tobacco company and interpret them for bergman .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in spite of the secrecy , wigand's former employers seem immediately to know wigand is talking to 60 minutes and he is warned off by former boss thomas sandefur played michael gambon in an all too brief but deliciously sinister role .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: and so the game begins .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: wigand is irate at his negative treatment for what he still considered continued to be loyalty to his agreement and his former employer .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: meanwhile someone is playing very rough with wigand and his family .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the film examines wigand and the pressures placed on his family as they are caught between two powerful giants .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: wigand has always wanted to make tobacco safer and has natural sympathies with getting the story out .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he and his family are assaulted psychologically and financially by the giant tobacco industry that had never lost a legal fight .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: al pacino is given top billing but the wigand family is the core of the insider .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the story is told slowly and in just a bit too much meticulous detail .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the film is 157 minutes and is an extremely demanding film for the audience .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the musical score by pieter bourke , lisa gerrard , and graeme revell is one of the worst in recent memory .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it puts ominous chords under some scenes and using voice in ways that become a distraction that gets in the way of the storytelling .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: also disturbing is the casting of christopher plummer as mike wallace .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: plummer and wallace are such different types and wallace is too well-known for even so good an actor as plummer to play him convincingly .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this film might have been a really engaging experience under another director's control .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: michael mann was the wrong person to helm this film and the insider lacks intensity because of his style .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i rate it a 4 on the 0 to 10 scale and a 0 on the -4 to +4 scale .
docs.label: negative
